item.title: Researchers find potential genetic clue to obesity
item.description: Researchers from Georgetown University Medical Center believe they have identified a genetic mutation that can lead to obesity.

item.title: Antibiotics reaching a dangerous crossroads, says World Health Organization
item.description: An increasing resistance to antibiotics could mean "the end of modern medicine as we know it," according to the director general of the World Health Organization.

item.title: 'Street Dogs' documentary features survival skills of LA strays
item.description: The film "Street Dogs of South Central" offers a glimpse into the daily life of a few of the approximately 30,000 stray dogs living in L.A.

item.title: What's the difference between self-cutting and suicide?
item.description: In the wake of a group self-cutting incident at Normandie Avenue Elementary, psychology experts clarify that self-cutting isn't always suicidal.

item.title: Study: Low health literacy connected to premature death
item.description: A new study suggests that people who have trouble understanding basic health information are at a greater risk of dying prematurely.

item.title: LAUSD confirms reports of group cutting at South LA school
item.description: L.A. Unified has confirmed reports that students at Normandie Avenue Elementary School last week took blades out of their pencil sharpeners and all began slicing their arms.

item.title: Homicide victim resource fair officially postponed
item.description: The annual Life After Uncivil Ruthless Acts (L.A.U.R.A.) Unity and Peace Resource Fair was planned for this Saturday, March 17 but has been postponed by event organizers due to rainy weather.

item.title: RAIN DELAY: Homicide victim resource fair may be postponed
item.description: The Life After Uncivil Ruthless Acts (L.A.U.R.A.) resource fair was planned for Saturday but may face rescheduling due to rain.

item.title: Women's History in South LA: Charlotta Bass
item.description: In recognition of Women's History Month, OnCentral is bringing you the stories of women who have come from or profoundly affected the character and culture of the South Los Angeles community.

item.title: New CDC ad campaign aims to shock smokers into quitting
item.description: After nearly 50 years of government warnings about the dangers of smoking, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is putting its money where its mouth is.

item.title: An oasis in a food desert: Central Avenue's farmers market
item.description: It's certainly not easy to find produce that's fresh off the farm in South L.A. among the McDonald's, Jack in the Boxes and convenience stores – but it's also not impossible.

item.title: Ortho Mattress donates beds, funds to South LA families in need
item.description: Ortho Mattress is partnering with A Place Called Home to provide beds for families in need. They've also started selling "Kenny Koala" plush toys and donating proceeds to the non-profit.

item.title: Under the radar: Living as an LGBT youth in South LA
item.description: Gina Perez, 17, is mostly like any other regular teen living in South L.A. - but from time to time she faces discrimination because she is gay.

item.title: Study: Fatty foods linked to low sperm count
item.description: First it was soda, then red meat – now this?

item.title: On patrol with a Southwest Division sergeant
item.description: LAPD Southwest Division Sergeant Carlton Brown took OnCentral's José Martinez on a ride-along and talked shootings, Shaft and Sam Goody's raids.
